Morata also played in back-to-back Champions League finals, appearing as a substitute in Real's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 2015 defeat. He initially came through the ranks at Real, debuting at 18 and scoring 10 goals for them.

Wilson was signed by Championship team Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013. He was released in May and is currently without a team. He played 51 times for Forest in his second spell there, having previously played for them for four seasons. He has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

The passage discusses Tesco, a British supermarket giant, exiting the US market by selling its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, which has been losing money since 2007. Key points include:

- Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business.
- Tesco will loan the new business around £80m and will incur a cost of £150m to dispose of the brand.
- Fresh & Easy operates 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona, with 50 stores expected to close.
- The buyer is Yucaipa, a Los Angeles based private equity company run by billionaire investor Ron Burkle.
- Tesco has the option to buy a stake if the business becomes profitable.
- Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits for 20 years in April.

The passage discusses an individual who initially faced racial abuse but overcame it. He considered representing France but is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. Additionally, the passage mentions a guide on how to get into martial arts.

The passage discusses the retreat of glaciers in the French Alps from the late 1960s to the late 2000s. Key points include:

- Glacier coverage decreased from 375 sq km to 275 sq km, a 26% loss over 40 years.
- The retreat is not uniform, with greater losses in southern sectors like Belledonne and Ecrins.
- The research, presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting, was conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues from the University of Savoie.
- Methods used included map archives, satellite imagery, aerial photographs, and manual inspection.
- The northern region, including Mont Blanc's La Mer de Glace, has seen less retreat due to higher elevation and more precipitation.
- The findings mirror retreats in other parts of the Alps across several nations.

The passage discusses the Scottish women's football team's qualifying campaign for a major competition. Key points include:

- The Scots have won all five qualifiers and a victory against Iceland could secure their place.
- Lisa Evans, a forward for the team, expresses the desire to qualify after previous failures.
- Iceland, ranked slightly higher than Scotland, is also unbeaten and the outcome of their matches will likely decide the group winner.
- Scotland is in a good position to qualify automatically without play-offs.
- Evans highlights the importance of fan support and the strength of the Icelandic team.
- The Scottish squad includes players from various international leagues, which benefits the national team.
- Evans praises the competitiveness of the German league and the positive impact of playing abroad on the national team.

Stuart Campbell was arrested in the west of England for alleged online harassment of a woman in south London over a two-year period. He was released on bail. Campbell, a blogger and former computer games reviewer who lives in Bath, denied the allegations, stating they were related to tweets that were not threatening. He accused the media of using innuendo to encourage speculation. The police are investigating the allegation. Campbell has been bailed until mid-September. He responded to a report of his arrest, reiterating that the allegations were only about tweets, none of which were threatening.

Peta suggests replacing the Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness with a fish, citing animal cruelty concerns. The mayor, Carl Macey, welcomes suggestions but doesn't expect much support for this change. The original Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned in 1908, is seen as a beloved symbol of the town. Peta's proposal aims to rebrand Skegness as a progressive destination. The mayor believes Jolly is not perceived as promoting animal cruelty and will consider the suggestion in council.

The passage describes a rugby match between Scotland and Georgia. Key points include:

- Georgia scored first with a try by Vasil Lobzhanidze.
- Scotland then took the lead with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime.
- Hamish Watson scored early in the second half, extending Scotland's lead.
- Lobzhanidze scored a second try for Georgia, followed by another try from Hogg for Scotland.
- Scotland dominated possession and territory, with Georgia struggling to gain control of the ball.
- The final score saw Scotland with a significant lead, reflecting their dominant performance.
- Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised the team's first-half performance and their ability to keep Georgia out of the game.
- The lineups for both Scotland and Georgia are provided at the end of the passage.

Tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge gave Widnes a 14-6 half-time lead, with Castleford loanee Paddy Flynn scoring for his parent club. Flynn scored again early in the second half, but tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor extended Widnes' lead to 38-12. Despite three quick tries from Castleford's Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick, Widnes held on for the win. The victory moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remains in sixth. Castleford suffered their fourth consecutive home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti, was released from Guantanamo Bay after a US review panel concluded he was not a continuing significant threat. He had been detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, charges he denies. His release came after a review in July and he is the first inmate to be freed since May. He will spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. His release brings the total number of inmates at Guantanamo down to 148.

Thousands attended the Anzac Day service at Hyde Park Corner and 400 participated in a parade before a wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. The first Anzac Day commemoration in the capital was in 1916, a year after the Gallipoli landings. The services have since become important for thousands of expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians to honor their countrymen and women in all wars. The Australian high commissioner to the UK, Alexander Downer, addressed the crowds, reflecting on the Gallipoli landings and the heroism of the Anzac troops. The ceremony at the Cenotaph included veterans, service personnel, and their families, with crowds lining the streets. The Gallipoli campaign was one of the bloodiest of the war.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old footballer, joined St Mirren in July and could debut against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has been maintaining his fitness. With nearly 400 senior appearances and two Scotland caps, he has played for teams like Bristol City and Brentford. St Mirren is eighth in the Championship, seven points above bottom team Alloa. Clarkson hopes to help the team win and climb the table.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. There were initial concerns about the workers' pension scheme, but Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that the new owners would honor all current agreements. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and its members currently have an alternative pension scheme that is unaffected by the takeover. Boparan Private Office confirmed the continuation of current pension arrangements. The new owner plans to restore Bernard Matthews to profitability through investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

The passage discusses issues surrounding a new ferry service at Cowes. Key points include:

- The ferry service, launched on 14 May, has experienced several problems, including breakdowns, groundings, suspensions due to training issues, and damage to cars during loading and unloading.
- Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the crossing would be free until 2 July due to these problems and to gather feedback. He also ordered a project review by auditors.
- Local businesses, such as shopkeeper Angie Booth, have been negatively impacted by the ferry's issues, with concerns about loss of trade.
- Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged the problems but considered them teething issues of a prototype. He mentioned that electrical problems had been fixed and ramp extensions were authorized to prevent vehicle scraping. He also said groundings had been resolved and compensation for local businesses was under discussion.

The passage discusses the implications of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. Here are the core pieces of information:

1. **Fishing Communities and Brexit**: Many UK fishing communities voted to leave the EU, hoping to regain control over UK waters and become a major fish-exporting nation.

2. **House of Lords Report**: The House of Lords EU Committee released a report warning that the UK fishing industry, which contributes 0.5% to GDP and employs 12,000 fishers, might be marginalized in Brexit negotiations.

3. **Market Access vs. Fishing Rights**: The report highlights that continued market access to the EU for UK fish exports may come at the price of allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters.

4. **Shared Fish Stocks and Trade-offs**: Most commercial fish stocks are in waters shared between the UK and other EU states, and Brexit will involve trade-offs regarding fishing rights and market access.

5. **Retaining Elements of CFP**: The report suggests retaining some elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) post-Brexit, such as scientifically-based quotas, and continuing international cooperation.

6. **Potential for Different Fisheries Regimes**: Leaving the EU could result in different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland.

7. **Industry Optimism**: Despite concerns, many in the fishing industry are optimistic about Brexit, believing it will bring more opportunities than threats.

8. **Government Response**: The UK government aims to ensure maximum freedom for British companies to trade with the single market and review fisheries management for fair access to quota and sustainable stocks.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or permitting indecent images to be taken between April 2004 and February 2014. He was sentenced to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and required to participate in a special program for sex offenders. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, he was removed from the teaching profession's register due to the nature of his offenses and the likelihood of recurring behavior. Geaney, aged 69 at sentencing, was not present at the hearing and is prohibited from re-registering for two years.

A fire on 2 March at a site on Duncan Street, operated by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited and managed by Asset and Land Group, caused travel disruptions. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the firm's waste acceptance license, with an appeal deadline of 7 August. The Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had visited the site nine times in the past year, finding it "broadly compliant" with safety laws. The EA revoked the site's environmental permit, requiring waste removal. The fire's cause is undetermined.

Syria is working to meet its chemical weapons destruction timeline but missed a deadline due to attacks on shipments by rebel groups. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad criticized U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, insisting that Syria only targets terrorist areas. The Syrian government denied reports of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, although fighting continues. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, with only 4% removed so far. Russia has set a March 1 deadline for Syria to transfer all chemical weapons to the coast. Despite delays, Syria maintains it is committed to fulfilling its obligations on time.

England won a Test match against Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, achieving their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 runs in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with taking four catches and claiming a wicket. Pakistan were bowled out for 198 and 234. Former England players and the coach praised Root's performance and England's overall dominance. Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledged their disappointment but hoped for improvement. The next Test match is scheduled at Edgbaston on August 3.

The passage discusses the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, launching a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. Key points include:

- Rochira will gather experiences from pensioners, their families, and friends to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies.
- She aims to highlight both good care and the impact of poor care, having noted unacceptable variations in care quality across Wales.
- The review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment.
- While Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims, it criticizes the exclusion of a provider expert on the main advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former midfielder, has been appointed as the new manager at Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin has been the player-manager at Arbroath, known as the Red Lichties, since 2010, and led them to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title in 2011. Arbroath was recently relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing at the bottom of League One in the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, praised the selection process and the cooperation of Arbroath's chairman. Sheerin has played for various Scottish clubs and also in Sweden, and he earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s.

**Concise Summary:**

- Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking.
- Swansea aims to appoint a new manager soon, with Paul Clement as the first choice.
- The club fears relegation and the challenge of returning to the Premier League.
- Swansea was promoted in 2011 and known for possession-based football.
- Curtis believes Swansea has lost its way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 due to frequent management changes and inadequate player replacements.
- He thinks the current squad can avoid relegation and reminds players of the club's history and importance to the area.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated human genome mapping by turning it into a competitive race, although this drew criticism from the scientific community. He is known for his confidence in his achievements and his wealth. After the human genome project, he focused on creating a synthetic life form, culminating in the creation of an organism called Synthia. Born in 1946, Venter initially struggled academically, but his experiences in the Vietnam War inspired him to pursue medicine and value time. He excelled in research and pioneered faster gene sequencing methods. He founded several institutions, including Celera Genomics and the J. Craig Venter Institute, and has also led projects to sequence marine microbe genomes. His work, though controversial, has significantly advanced genomics and has the potential for environmental applications.

The passage discusses the state of apprenticeships in England compared to other European countries, particularly Germany. Key points include:

1. **Quality and Quantity**: Many apprenticeships in England are considered low quality and too short. Fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 apprenticeships are rated at level three (equivalent to A-level).

2. **Comparison with Germany**: Only 20% of employers in England offer apprenticeships, compared to 51% in Germany. In Germany, 570,000 new apprenticeships are for young people, with 90% equivalent to A-levels.

3. **Complexity**: England's vocational system has 18,000 different qualifications, while Germany has 330.

4. **Age and Competition**: Since 2010, 58% of apprenticeships have been below level three and aimed at those over 25. There are 11 young people competing for each apprenticeship.

5. **Recommendations**: The report calls for an expansion of apprenticeships to 300,000 new starts each year, with the majority at level three or above.

6. **Responses**: The Association of Colleges and the Department for Education acknowledge the need for reform and improvement in apprenticeship standards.

7. **Social Mobility**: Sir Peter Lampl, chairman of the Sutton Trust, emphasizes the importance of good apprenticeships for social mobility and economic competitiveness.

The Briton, Sarah Storey, won a time trial in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. She has the opportunity to secure a 17th title in the upcoming road race. Storey, 37, is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, with 22 medals including 11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze in cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. She aims for further success at the Rio de Janeiro Games. Storey began her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, and switched to cycling in 2005. She has won 21 world titles in both sports.

The passage discusses the expulsion of Hereford United, known as the Bulls, from the Football Conference due to their financial struggles. Key points include:

- Hereford's financial troubles came to light after they avoided relegation on the final day of the season, causing Chester to be relegated instead.
- The Conference gave Hereford multiple deadlines to pay their debts, totaling £148,000 to football creditors, but the club failed to meet them.
- Hereford was taken over by Tommy Agombar, but the club still faced outstanding debts and tax demands.
- The Hereford United Supporters' Trust made an offer to buy the club and clear debts, but this was not accepted.
- Hereford's financial situation worsened due to falling attendance after their relegation from the Football League in 2012.
- The Conference ultimately expelled Hereford, and Chester FC took their place in the Conference Premier.
- Former Hereford players Kingsley James and Dan Lloyd-Weston moved to other clubs due to unpaid salaries.

The passage discusses the international career of a former Manchester City player, aged 30. Key points include:

- He earned 61 caps for England, debuting in 2009.
- He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships but played minimally at Euro 2016.
- He decided to retire from international football, wishing the team well.
- He is the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, starting in 2004.
- He scored one international goal, in a 2014 World Cup qualifier against Moldova.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. He was known for his work with leading orchestras worldwide and founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, which he directed for about 30 years. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including notable recordings like Handel's Messiah (1980). Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held various positions, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and the Handel and Haydn Society in Boston. He was also a tutor and honorary professor at several universities. Colleagues remember him for his generosity, academic prowess, and significant contributions to historically informed music performances. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for a later date.

The passage discusses a boy from Northern Ireland who was removed from mainstream schooling due to coping difficulties. His parents requested a place at a special school but were told all were full. The boy's mother expressed concern about his isolation and the lack of capacity in special needs schools. Recently, they were informed of a potential place opening up. The Education Authority acknowledged the issue but did not comment on the specific case, mentioning a review to ensure special school places are available close to children's residences.

The passage discusses a takeover bid by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) for the Newport Gwent Dragons, with Rodney Parade seen as a rugby venue. Newport County has a lease to use the ground until 2023 and expects their contract to be honored. The WRU's takeover will be voted on by shareholders on May 9. County is currently two points clear of relegation in League Two, with survival possible if they win their next game and rivals Hartlepool lose. Relegation would be seen as a significant blow to the fans and the city of Newport. Additionally, the WRU plans to install an artificial surface at Rodney Parade, which is against Football League rules.

The passage discusses the experiences of a man from Sierra Leone who was kidnapped as a teenager by rebels during the civil war and forced to commit atrocities. After escaping, he met a preacher who encouraged him to rebuild his life and contribute positively to society. When the Ebola crisis hit in 2014, he and others established a clinic and conducted educational outreach, saving many lives. The country was recently declared free of the virus, which had caused nearly 4,000 deaths there. The man now focuses on investing in young people to build a better future.

The passage discusses the successful fundraising campaign to save the Wedgwood Museum's collection, which was at risk of being auctioned off to pay the pottery firm's pension debt. Key points include:

- The collection consists of about 80,000 items, including art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs.
- A public fundraising campaign led by the Art Fund hit its target in a month.
- The collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, and will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum.
- The museum inherited the pension debt after the firm collapsed in 2009 and went into administration in 2010.
- The sale was completed, and the collection was saved from being sold and scattered around the globe.
- The collection is important for Staffordshire and Britain's cultural development, as noted by Alison Wedgwood and Tristram Hunt MP.

The passage discusses a potential deal involving Mark Wright buying 20% of Billericay football club, which would also make him a club director. Billericay is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. The club was recently taken over by Glenn Tamplin, who is investing significantly in the club. They have also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

In the football match between Blackpool and Colchester United, Blackpool scored first with a goal by Jamille Matt in the 12th minute. Colchester equalized through Kurtis Guthrie from a corner after 17 minutes. Both teams had chances to score again, with notable saves from Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray received a red card in injury time. The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

The passage discusses plans to transform the disused Fawley power station chimney into the tallest attraction south of London's Shard, as part of a £1bn "merchant city" development. The power station, which closed in 2013 after over 40 years of operation, will be repurposed with a petal-shaped glass structure, surrounded by a marina, housing, and restaurants. The development also includes fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. Building could start in 2018, pending outline planning permission. The 198-meter-high chimney, which has dominated the Solent skyline since the power station was commissioned in 1971, will be the centerpiece of the development. The 300-acre site was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016.

A 23-year-old British cyclist, Latham, won a bronze medal at the Hong Kong championships in a race where Poland's Adrian Teklinski won gold and Germany's Lucass Liss took silver. In other events, the British men's team pursuit lost the bronze medal to Italy, and Joe Truman was outclassed in the men's keirin semi-final. The women's team pursuit finished fifth, with Olympic gold medallist Elinor Barker joining the young team. Katy Marchant, an Olympic bronze medallist, was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint. Latham's medal was GB's second, following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch.

Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell until 2006, will briefly return to EastEnders for Barbara Windsor's final episodes. Windsor's character, Peggy, returned to reveal her cancer had recurred and will die in upcoming episodes. Kemp's return will reunite the Mitchell brothers, Grant and Phil (Steve McFadden), with their mother one last time. Grant Mitchell, a memorable character from the soap's history, was involved in various family dramas. The reunion will allow Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden to showcase their acting skills in emotional scenes.

Sadio Mane scored two quick goals as Spurs, the second-placed team, struggled at Anfield. Spurs manager Pochettino criticized his team's lack of desire and readiness to fight for the Premier League title. Chelsea could extend their lead if they win their next match. Spurs have had poor away form against top-six sides, with only one win in their last 17 such matches. Pochettino and former player Danny Murphy both expressed concern over Spurs' away performance and mindset.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which had been in power for 16 years. The PDP lost key northern states and control of Adamawa, but retained Rivers State. The APC made historic gains, particularly in the north and Lagos, but failed to win in any oil-producing states. The elections were generally peaceful but had instances of violence. The PDP will need to rebuild under new leadership after facing allegations of corruption and criticism for not adequately addressing the Boko Haram insurgency.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) will occur in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19 to 22 July. Festival-goers can use an app to access online information, videos, and band interviews by scanning signs and posters. Notable acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Lucy Spraggan. The festival's director, Caroline Maclennan, highlights that the augmented reality experience will enhance enjoyment and allow global interaction. The app will provide real-time updates, ticket purchasing, and a sense of the festival's atmosphere.

The passage discusses the following core pieces of information:

1. **School Funding and Management Changes**: Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated. Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running these schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, face similar consequences if concerns are not addressed.

2. **Trojan Horse Scandal**: A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools reported that parents tried to undermine her authority and spoke to inspectors about her. She felt alone and considered quitting her job.

3. **Ofsted Reports**: Ofsted published 21 reports into schools allegedly targeted in a hardline Muslim takeover, with five schools, including Park View and Oldknow, rated inadequate.

4. **Birmingham City Council's Involvement**: The council will work with Saltley School, the only local authority school placed in special measures, to install a temporary governing board.

5. **Criticism and Actions**: Lord Nash criticized Park View for not promoting pupils' development and gave the trust until July 4 to respond. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock received similar demands, including ending unfavorable treatment of non-Muslims and segregation.

6. **Culture of Fear**: Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw reported a "culture of fear and intimidation" in Birmingham schools and an "organized campaign" to impose a narrow, faith-based ideology.

7. **Parental Criticism**: Parents criticized Ofsted's reports, accusing inspectors of bias and pushing personal agendas. They invited Education Secretary Michael Gove for an open meeting.

8. **School Responses**: Park View School plans to challenge the Ofsted report. Saltley School aims to improve its rating, with a new associate head teacher focusing on moving forward.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court alleges that eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation, leading to his preventable death from increased pressure in his skull due to a build-up of fluid in his brain. Rose is charged with gross negligence manslaughter, which she denies. The prosecution argues that Rose's conduct was so far below the expected standard that it was criminal. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity and sending sexually explicit material to her family. He was convicted at Dundee Sheriff Court and sentenced at the High Court in Edinburgh. Weatherhogg, 42, was also placed on the sex offenders register. The victim felt "blackmailed" by him, and the judge noted that his actions warranted a sentence reflecting society's disapproval. Despite being a first offender, he poses a moderate risk of re-offending.

Ireland scored 165-5 in a T20 match against Afghanistan, with Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 not out), and William Porterfield (39) contributing significantly. Afghanistan won by reaching 171-4 with two overs remaining, led by Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47). The teams will play another T20 match at the same venue on Friday. Ireland's captain Porterfield admitted they fell short of their target score and didn't execute well with the ball. Additionally, Ireland's paceman Boyd Rankin is out for the T20s due to a back problem but is expected to return for the upcoming ODIs.

The passage discusses the transfer of Neymar to Barcelona for £48.6m, with his parents receiving £34m. The total cost to the club, including all fees and wages, amounts to £106.8m. Barcelona faces allegations of misappropriation and tax-related crimes, which the club denies. The former president, Sandro Rosell, resigned due to these accusations. Barcelona made an additional tax payment of €13.55m to cover potential interpretations of their obligations. Neymar has scored 10 goals in 25 appearances this season.

The passage discusses the murders of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, on a beach in Koh Tao on September 15. UK Metropolitan Police officers assisted Thai police, who have two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, in custody. The suspects are charged with conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty. UK detectives have completed their work and will report back to the families. Concerns have been raised about the investigation, including the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects. The UK police visit was agreed upon after a meeting between the Thai Prime Minister and the British Prime Minister. Post-mortem examinations revealed Miller died from drowning and a head injury, while Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police claim DNA found on Witheridge matched the suspects.

The passage discusses the Scottish women's football team's qualifying campaign for a major tournament. Here are the core pieces of information:

1. **Scotland's Performance**: The Scots have won all five qualifiers and a win against Iceland could secure their place in the finals.
2. **Previous Disappointments**: The team has previously missed out on qualification for Euro 2013 and the 2015 World Cup, losing in the play-offs.
3. **Upcoming Matches**: Scotland will play Iceland (ranked one place above them) twice, with these matches likely deciding the group winner.
4. **Qualification Format**: The best six of the eight group runners-up also qualify automatically, putting Scotland in a good position.
5. **Player Insights**: Lisa Evans, a Bayern Munich forward, shares her experiences and the team's determination to qualify.
6. **International Players**: The Scottish squad includes 12 players who play outside Scotland, bringing diverse experiences to the national team.
7. **Benefits of Overseas Play**: Evans believes playing in top leagues abroad improves the national team due to different cultures and playing styles.

The passage discusses Apple's implementation of a two-step verification system to prevent unauthorized access to iCloud accounts, following a celebrity photo leak. The process involves entering a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after inputting a username and password. While this system was previously available, it did not apply to iCloud backups, allowing hackers to use software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker to download data. Apple's changes now secure this process, but the two-step verification remains an opt-in feature, which experts suggest should be made default. Additionally, Apple plans to encourage users to enable this feature and use stronger passwords.

UKIP won the election with a spending of £2,956,737, while the Conservatives spent £2,980,815. The Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575 and lost all but one of their MEPs. Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339. The campaign period was from 23 January to 22 May. The spending per vote was 68p for UKIP, 26p for Labour, 79p for Conservatives, and £1.45 for Liberal Democrats. The Green Party spent £534,249, which is 43p per vote. The total spending by the six highest-spending parties was £9,347,087. All parties except Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually agreed to cancel his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals and could play against Barrow on 18 February. He has previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Torquay United (the Gulls) manager Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams and has played for several Irish clubs. His transfer is pending international clearance. Nicholson appreciates Anderson's leadership and Keating's hunger. The Gulls are currently four points above relegation, with one win in their last six games.

The passage reports that a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. The horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," according to the British Horseracing Authority. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had not collapsed before and had no significant underlying health issues. The horse had notable wins in the past, including the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. His trainer, Oliver Sherwood, described him as the "horse of a lifetime." The cause of death is reported as a rare haemorrhage, with no confirmed link to his previous tendency to overheat.

The passage discusses the farewell speeches of several Members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs) who are stepping down ahead of an election on 5 May. Key points include:

1. **Emotional Farewells**: Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was visibly emotional during the farewell speeches of Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond.

2. **Alex Salmond's Speech**: Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, emphasized Scotland's diversity and strength. He also criticized the Scotland Bill for not fulfilling alleged promises made during the referendum campaign.

3. **Duncan McNeil's Speech**: McNeil, a Labour MSP since 1999, warned that Holyrood needs to learn from Westminster, particularly in ensuring accountability and scrutiny.

4. **Annabel Goldie's Speech**: Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, joked about her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

5. **Upcoming Election**: The speeches took place ahead of the Scottish Parliament election on 5 May.

The passage discusses a live-action film adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast" set to be released on March 17, 2017. Key cast members include Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Kevin Kline as Maurice. The star playing Mrs. Potts, the teapot housekeeper, is also mentioned. Bill Condon will direct the film, with production starting in May at Shepperton Studios.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decisions regarding the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST. Ninety-six football fans were fatally injured in the disaster, and last year, new inquests concluded that the fans had been unlawfully killed. The CPS has been considering evidence against 23 suspects, with 15 related to the disaster's causes and 8 to police conduct afterwards. Margaret Aspinall, who lost her son in the disaster and chairs the Hillsborough Family Support Group, expressed anticipation and a desire for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, with a former inmate claiming the jail is "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A local resident reported witnessing such incidents four times in two weeks. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the problem and is working to address it, although they deny any evidence of drones being used. New laws have been introduced to jail those who smuggle packages into prisons for up to two years.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being hit by a car driven by Brian Wright, 55, outside Bedford Road Lower School, Kempston, last December. Wright, who is on trial for causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light or Blackburn. Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse, stating he was deeply sorry for the impact on Blackburn and her family. The trial is ongoing.

Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner, will miss the Commonwealth Games next year due to her veterinary medicine studies. Her exams in May conflict with the April event. She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000m. Muir is considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target. She is optimistic about her future, hoping to participate in at least two or three more Olympics.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old from County Kildare, Ireland, went missing after leaving a Christmas party in December 2000. He was last seen on CCTV talking to an unidentified man dressed in black outside his workplace, Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, and later on Haddington Road. In April, detectives released the enhanced footage and appealed for the man to come forward. A search began on Saturday morning in a three-acre woodland area in Chapelizod, Dublin, near the R112 road, which will involve excavations and is expected to take several weeks. This search is part of a complete review of Deely's disappearance conducted by a team of six detectives earlier this year. The man in the CCTV footage remains unidentified.

Del Potro, ranked 165th after injury problems, defeated Swiss player Wawrinka with a score of 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3. He will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Del Potro, who has had multiple wrist operations, is playing his first Grand Slam since 2014. Meanwhile, Nick Kyrgios came from behind to beat Dustin Brown and will face Feliciano Lopez in the third round. The winner of that match will play either Andy Murray or John Millman. Additionally, Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga secured routine victories in their matches.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against Caf but apologized and secured their participation. Morocco was initially banned from the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw but was reinstated after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban. Morocco had been punished for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 tournament was also in doubt after a controversial quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea in 2015, but they reconciled with Caf and will compete in Group A, while Morocco is in Group F.

The passage discusses the decline of the McLaren Formula 1 team from its past successes. Key points include:

- McLaren has won 182 races, 12 drivers' championships, and 8 constructors' titles, but now aims for mid-grid positions.
- The team's slump began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and current problems lie with the Honda power-unit.
- McLaren's last constructors' title was in 1998. They were involved in scandals in 2007 and 2009.
- The team's history has been a cycle of triumph and decline. Ron Dennis, who led them to past successes, is currently trying to revive the team.
- Fernando Alonso, a two-time champion, joined McLaren in 2015 believing in their potential to win again with Honda.
- McLaren's leadership believes they are making progress and will win championships again, but currently, they only have their belief to rely on.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 for a sudden death. Police found people still at the bar and till receipts showed alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. The court ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, were charged with allowing consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge criticized O'Neill's record and fined her £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000. The defense admitted that licensing laws were not strictly followed.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points and making eight 3-pointers to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. He surpassed his previous record of 272 three-pointers set two years ago. Klay Thompson scored 26 points to help the Warriors avoid a three-game losing streak. LaMarcus Aldridge had 27 points and Damian Lillard added 20 for the Blazers. In another game, Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds as the Chicago Bulls beat the Miami Heat 89-78, overcoming a 19-point halftime deficit. Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson each scored 14 points for the Bulls, while Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds for the Heat. Dwyane Wade scored only nine points for Miami.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were tricked into believing they were meeting a competition winner at Melwood, only to be surprised by YouTube star Bas van Velzen, a free-kick specialist. Van Velzen impressed the players with his skills, and they participated in a free-kick challenge together. Balotelli was particularly pleased with his own successful free-kick. Van Velzen expressed his excitement about the experience and revealed a t-shirt with Balotelli's famous slogan at the end.

The passage discusses the benefits of oophorectomy (ovary removal) for women diagnosed with breast cancer who carry the BRCA1 gene mutation. Key points include:

- Women with the BRCA1 gene mutation have a 50-80% lifetime risk of developing breast cancer.
- A study found that BRCA1 carriers who had their ovaries removed after breast cancer diagnosis reduced their risk of dying from breast cancer by over 60%.
- The study involved 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations, with nearly half undergoing oophorectomy.
- The 20-year survival rate for the entire group was 77.4%.
- Oophorectomy was associated with a 65% reduction in death from all causes for BRCA1 carriers.
- The protective effect of oophorectomy was apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years.
- The procedure was particularly effective for women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer.
- Actress Angelina Jolie, a BRCA1 carrier, had an oophorectomy and a double mastectomy to reduce her cancer risk.
- The study suggests that oophorectomy should be discussed as a treatment option for BRCA1 carriers with early-stage breast cancer.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by an Amtrak train (the Carolinian) on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina. The train was traveling from Charlotte to New York City. None of the 166 passengers were injured, though one fell ill during the delay. The train was delayed for about 2 hours and 45 minutes. The Lowes may have lived in a homeless camp, according to a man who met them while collecting scrap metal. Durham is about 25 miles northwest of the train's next destination, Raleigh.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, fled Colombia and became an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years, expecting U.S. citizenship in return. He was a key asset in operations against figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his contributions, Toro is now facing deportation after retiring due to declining health. The DEA has not assisted him with his citizenship, and he fears for his life if sent back to Colombia. Toro's former handler and colleagues advocate for him, but he remains in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits without a green card or passport. His final temporary visa expired on January 1, and he may go into hiding.

The U.S. body that regulates internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating the Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for using the new '.sucks' domain name to extract high fees from celebrities and companies seeking to protect their reputations. Notable examples include Kevin Spacey, who reportedly paid to have his '.sucks' domain taken down, and major brands like YouTube, Bing, Visa, and Bank of America that have purchased their respective '.sucks' domains. ICANN has sent a letter to U.S. and Canadian regulators to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal, following complaints from an advisory panel of industry groups and companies. Vox Populi has been charging around $2,499 a year for these domains, a practice criticized as predatory and a "shakedown scheme" by the advisory body.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her stillborn baby boy was found in a village pond. The case was reopened and the mother was identified through DNA testing. She had concealed her pregnancy and the birth, and the baby was later found by teenagers. The mother was initially suspected of infanticide, but the charge was dropped. The baby, now named Peter, was reburied, and a support group provided a new headstone. The mother remains on bail while authorities decide on potential charges for failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from Young's moving taxi. Young had mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to avoid paying the fare and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank. Hicks jumped from the vehicle traveling at over 20mph and now requires round-the-clock care. The High Court ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages, estimated to be around 50% of the requested amount, likely hundreds of thousands of pounds. The exact compensation is yet to be decided.

Tornado sirens went off in Kansas on Wednesday night as several storms brought reports of tornadoes. One tornado was reported near Goddard, moving northeast and missing Wichita but posing risks to other communities. Nighttime tornadoes were highlighted as particularly dangerous. Other tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas, with three sightings near Aetna. Kansas wasn't the only state affected; a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage and flooding. On Thursday, more storms were expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight fight in New Jersey. Rockhold is aiming for his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot. He plans to be aggressive and "be the bull" to Machida's "matador" style, utilizing his mixed martial arts skills to dominate the fight. Machida, also coming off a victory, is confident he can win by applying his style and technique, and believes the winner deserves a title shot. Both fighters respect each other but are determined to win.

An aeroplane made a gear-up landing at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, skidding along the runway on its belly. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, realized his mistake and took off again, flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where he landed safely. The most common cause of such landings is human error. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manuel Pellegrini, the manager of Manchester City, has expressed disappointment in Yaya Toure's performance this season but pledged to support the midfielder until the end of the season. The club is reportedly open to offers for Toure as they aim to rejuvenate their squad. Toure, who has been criticized for his performances, is determined not to leave. Pellegrini acknowledged Toure's underperformance and dismissed suggestions that he needs a break. City faces West Ham amidst a poor run of form and injury to captain Vincent Kompany. Goalkeeper Joe Hart admitted the players have let the manager down. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce warned left-back Aaron Cresswell, who is attracting interest from top clubs, not to make the same mistake as other English players by moving to City and risking limited playing time.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will remain in the UK after his sentence was dropped. He was sentenced to seven years in Italy in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra but fled to Britain in the 1990s. Although he lost his extradition battle in February, it was later revealed that his case expired last October, and his European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn. Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once more than double the time of the penalty has passed. Rancadore's solicitor, Karen Todner, expects the Italian government to withdraw the arrest warrant, allowing Rancadore to live in peace in England with his family. The case will still be heard by the Italian Supreme Court. Rancadore was first arrested in 2013 and had lived under the name Marc Skinner for two decades. Legal experts criticized the time and money spent on the case.

In the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. This will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race. The line-up consists of seven runners, including Somersby. McCoy's final day of rides as a professional jockey will be confirmed on Friday morning. Notably, McCoy announced his retirement after riding Mr. Mole to victory at Newbury in February.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Victim:** Marcia Trimble Ritter, murdered in 1975.
- **Mother:** Virginia Trimble Ritter, recently saw crime scene photos.
- **Murderer:** Jerome Sydney Barrett, convicted in 2009, sentenced to 44 years.
- **Crime Details:** Marcia was raped, choked to death, and found 33 days after disappearance.
- **Mother's Reaction:** Wants revenge, regrets not seeing photos earlier.
- **Case History:** Unsolved for 33 years, previously wrong accusation, DNA match led to Barrett's arrest.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, is determined to win the Masters to complete his career grand slam, becoming only the sixth player to achieve this feat. He considers his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 as the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons. McIlroy has had limited success at the Masters, with only one top-10 finish in six appearances. He believes it's unthinkable to not win at least one green jacket during his career and hopes to win multiple times at Augusta. Despite personal distractions, McIlroy finds the golf course to be his sanctuary and is eager to focus on playing his best.

The passage summarizes trending stories from a week, including:

- Four rainbows appearing in the New York area after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis.
- The practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes in rural China, which is being cracked down on.
- Actor Robert Downey Jr. (RDJ) becoming agitated during an interview about his private life.
- A new trend called the #kyliejennerchallenge, where people attempt to plump their lips to look like Kylie Jenner.
- A 102-year-old woman, Alice Barker, revisiting her past with the help of filmmakers.
- A controversial prom proposal that referenced bombs.
- Ewan McGregor being cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast."
- Johnny Depp's unrecognizable appearance in the "Black Mass" trailer.
- A creative pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air."
- A military dad photobombing his son.

These stories gained significant attention and discussion on social media during the week.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Hospitalizations:** 272 children with fetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalized in England in the past year.
- **Prevalence:** About 1 in 100 babies in the UK may have learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to prenatal alcohol exposure, according to the World Health Organization.
- **Effects:** Fetal alcohol syndrome can cause lifelong issues, including learning difficulties, behavioral problems, and physical deformities.
- **Case Example:** Niamh Brown, a 15-year-old with fetal alcohol syndrome, needs assistance with daily tasks and will never live independently.
- **Guidelines:** The UK government advises pregnant women not to drink alcohol or to consume no more than two units twice a week. Some experts believe the guidance should advise no alcohol consumption during pregnancy.

An axe-wielding robber, Shaun Andrew McKerry, was jailed for six years after a failed robbery attempt at Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham. McKerry, a former juvenile offender known as "Boomerang Boy" for his tendency to return home after committing crimes, entered the store at 8 pm on March 15, demanding cash from an assistant while waving an axe. The store owner, Sab Dhillon, tackled McKerry, and his wife, Sam, hit McKerry with a baseball bat, disarming him. The police arrived shortly after and arrested McKerry, who had previously been convicted for various crimes, including shoplifting, burglary, and aggravated vehicle-taking.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow (23), Simon Radford (31), Craig Stoner (24), and Darren Smalley (35)—are charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a party in a Canadian barracks. They must stay in Nova Scotia until their trial and have been given unusual bail conditions, including surrendering their passports and living at the Stadacona naval base in Halifax. The alleged assault occurred on April 10 after a hockey game. The four men, who were playing for the Royal Navy ice hockey team, are accused of having sexual intercourse with the victim, who is in her early 20s. They have been ordered to return to court on May 27 and must not leave Nova Scotia or contact the victim and six witnesses. The sailors are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which are punishable by up to 14 years in prison. The investigation is ongoing, and additional charges may result from forensic tests.

A mother, Valerie Jackson from Las Vegas, has a four-year-old son, RJ, who suffers from Netherton's syndrome, an incredibly rare skin disease that makes his skin appear red and scaly. Due to his condition, she regularly applies creams to prevent his skin from drying out. Recently, while shopping, a stranger mistook RJ's condition for signs of abuse and reported her to the police. Armed police surrounded her, but after she explained the situation, they apologized. RJ's condition is so rare that it often attracts stares and cruel comments from adults, with some even accusing her of burning her son. Despite the challenges, Valerie sees her son as beautiful and hopes that his condition will be better understood as he grows older. Netherton's syndrome is a rare congenital skin disease with no cure, but symptoms may improve with time.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" advertisements featuring a bikini-clad model, Renee Somerfield, in the London Underground. Key points include:

- The ads sparked outrage among feminists and body image campaigners, with a Change.org petition garnering over 50,000 signatures calling for their removal.
- The Advertising Standards Authority received over 200 complaints about the ads promoting an unhealthy body image.
- Transport for London (TfL) confirmed the posters would be removed as the advertising period ended, and they would consider the public reaction for future similar ads.
- A protest against Protein World was organized in Hyde Park, and the ads caused a significant backlash on social media.
- Protein World defended their campaign, claiming the image was unedited and engaging with critics on social media.
- The Advertising Standards Authority received 216 complaints and was assessing them for potential action.
- Despite the controversy, Protein World's head of global marketing deemed the campaign a success and stated they would not change their advertising methods.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Fare Hikes:** Rail firms plan fare increases of up to 87% just after the general election, despite party leaders' pledges to freeze prices.
- **Prime Minister's Intervention:** David Cameron has asked First Great Western (FGW) to 'urgently review' its decision to almost double some fares between London and the Cotswolds, passing through his Witney constituency.
- **Example of Increase:** Charlbury to London off-peak return will increase from £33.30 to £62.40 (87%).
- **Reason for Increase:** FGW aims to align the North Cotswolds route with other services.
- **Other Increases:** Notable hikes include Crewe to Northampton (23%), Stafford to Liverpool (24.5%), and Manchester to Stoke (22%).
- **Companies' Responses:** FGW offers cheaper advance singles. Virgin claims most increases are on 'Virgin Trains-only fares,' which are cheaper than rivals'.

A 66-year-old former soldier, John Young, was blinded in one eye after being hit by a brick thrown by vandals at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. Young and his new wife, Elaine, were writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts when the attack occurred. Young confronted the attackers after they smashed his window with stones, and was struck in the eye by a brick. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight. Police have launched an investigation but found no apparent motive. The couple, who had been married for just three weeks, now plans to move away due to fear for their safety.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a new one-year contract extension following a successful return from injury. Poynton missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident that also resulted in the death of his father. After undergoing an ankle operation, he made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. The contract commits him to the county until the end of the 2016 season. Graeme Welch, Derbyshire's elite performance director, praised Poynton's character and hard work during his recovery and expressed hope that the new contract will boost his confidence for the upcoming season.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw, who was diagnosed with neuroblastoma (a rare and aggressive form of cancer) in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, has been declared cancer-free. Harley wore a Ninja Turtle mask during his radiotherapy treatment to feel stronger. His story gained global attention, and he received Ninja Turtle presents from Nickelodeon. After intensive treatment, including chemotherapy, surgery, stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, doctors have announced that Harley is now free of cancer. He will continue to have regular check-ups. Harley's bravery has been recognized with a Cancer Research UK Little Star award, and he has become the face of the charity's Kids and Teens campaign. Neuroblastoma affects fewer than 100 children in the UK each year and can spread to various parts of the body. The cause is unknown, and symptoms vary based on the tumor's location. Treatment options include surgery, chemotherapy, antibody treatment, and radiotherapy.

**Concise Summary:**

- Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career.
- Grealish, 19, impressed in Villa's FA Cup win over Liverpool and is wanted by both the Republic of Ireland and England.
- Sherwood wants Grealish to prioritize his club performance to have more international options.
- Grealish's dad, Kevin, agrees that his son should concentrate on club football first.
- Grealish is expected to choose between Ireland and England at the end of the season.

The passage discusses the varying landing fees for private jets at different airports worldwide. Key points include:

- Landing fees can differ dramatically, with some airports charging thousands.
- The market for private jet travel is substantial, worth trillions in the US and Europe.
- The busiest times for private jet travel are during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix.
- The most expensive airports for landing fees are primarily in Japan, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo being the most expensive, charging £4,559 ($6,850).
- Other airports in the top 10 include Narita International Airport (Tokyo), Kansai International Airport (Osaka), and surprisingly, Bristol Airport (UK) and Darwin International Airport (Australia).
- The only US airport in the top 10 is LaGuardia in New York.
- Salzburg Airport in Austria and Dublin Airport in Ireland are also among the top 10 most expensive.
- The fees are based on a 767-400 aircraft, often customized for private use.

The passage describes a video where Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, takes her dogs Cooper and Daisy to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. Cooper quickly eats the ice cream, while Daisy takes a few licks. Gallegos mentions that Cooper always eats quickly, and she ensures Daisy gets her share first. The video has been watched over seven million times. Some viewers criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs ice cream, but she insists it's fine, citing her experience with dogs and their health. Another video shows the dogs enjoying a 'pup-uccino' at Starbucks, which is just whipped cream in a cup.

Gary Locke, initially the assistant manager at Kilmarnock, has been appointed as the permanent manager after signing a three-year deal. He took over the team in February following the departure of Allan Johnston and has since lost only one game out of seven. Locke will address the media at a press conference on Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, claims that a school threatened to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the essential oils he wears to help manage his condition. Teachers at Seminole County Elementary reportedly complained that the oils, manufactured by doTERRA, were a distraction because of their smell. Kemp applies the oils to Logan's head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. Despite the school's threats, Kemp insists she will continue using the oils, which include scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood. However, the Lake County School District later stated they would not suspend Logan, citing it as a health issue.

A fire destroyed a beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, the Hamptons, on Wednesday at 3 PM. Key details:

- 90 condos were engulfed in flames before the building collapsed.
- The fire was intense, with smoke visible from three miles away and paint melting off nearby buildings.
- 12 fire crews attempted to control the flames but could not enter the buildings.
- The cause of the fire is unknown, but it's being investigated with claims it started near a parked car.
- The complex, named Sandpiper, is used as a holiday home between May and November.
- Residents and the building manager lost their homes and belongings.

The passage discusses the Queen's lifelong love for horses, highlighting her recent ride on her Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, at the age of 88. She is known for not wearing a riding helmet, preferring a silk scarf instead. The Queen has been riding since she was four, and she breeds several horse and pony breeds, including Fell ponies. Despite a knee injury that has reduced her riding time, she remains an enthusiastic equestrienne. The passage also provides historical context about Fell ponies, noting their ancient lineage and various uses over time.

An argument over noise levels between two Brisbane neighbors ended in tragedy with one man dead and the other charged with manslaughter. Leon Yeaman, 55, was allegedly killed by a single punch to the head from Phillip Pama, 28, during a dispute outside their North Brisbane homes. Yeaman was reportedly making noise in his yard around 9 PM, disturbing Pama, a shift worker who was sleeping. Pama's lawyer claimed Yeaman was known for getting drunk and playing loud music. Pama confronted Yeaman, and the situation escalated, leading to the fatal punch. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene. Pama, a married father of three with no history of violence, was granted conditional bail and is due to appear in court on May 18.

A 52-year-old music teacher, Yulia Simonova, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former pupil and lover, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the task. Police set up a sting operation, with an undercover officer posing as a hitman, and filmed Simonova detailing her gruesome requests. She was arrested and now faces up to 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Vanya expressed relief and hoped for a lengthy imprisonment for Simonova.

Jose Mourinho, the 52-year-old Chelsea football manager, discusses his strong faith in God, stating he prays daily but not about football. He separates his professional and family life, never discussing football with his wife, Matilde Faria. Mourinho and his family have experienced poverty and worked with the World Food Programme. He believes he is a good person, despite his competitive and emotional professional demeanor. Chelsea is currently at the top of the league. Mourinho was previously fined for comments about a perceived campaign against Chelsea. He has a wife and two children.

Bob Barker, who hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years before retiring in 2007, returned to host a portion of the show on its April 1 edition. At 91, Barker effortlessly handled the first pricing game, "Lucky Seven," before passing the hosting duties back to Drew Carey. Despite being away from the show for eight years, Barker performed seamlessly.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. at 12:30 AM on Friday for attempting to break into a house and destruction of property. He was charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property. Baldwin, who works with the Foreign Missions Branch, had his security clearance revoked and was put on leave. His arrest follows another incident where a high-ranking supervisor was put on leave for misconduct. These incidents are under investigation and have negatively impacted the agency responsible for protecting the president.

A freelance photographer, Atif Saeed, risked his life to photograph a hungry lion from just 10 feet away in Lahore's Safari Park. He left his car and lay on the ground with only his camera. The lion noticed him due to the camera's shutter sound and acted aggressively, forcing Saeed to quickly retreat to his car. Saeed later admitted that he wouldn't do it again, describing the encounter as "pretty close."

The New York City police have released an image of a heart tattoo with the name 'Monique' to identify a woman found dead on a Brooklyn street on March 22. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn and later pronounced dead. The cause of death is still under investigation. Anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009. They couldn't afford to buy property, so they created a solar-powered, wood and steel home over a year and a half. The home is nearly self-sufficient, with water from a nearby spring and a power bill of just $25. It features a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and is surrounded by nature in Nelson, New Zealand. The project cost around $25,000.

The passage discusses a study that found children who share iPads in class perform better in early literacy tests than those who don't. The research, conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, involved 352 kindergarten students and showed that shared iPad users scored around 30 points higher than solo iPad users and non-iPad users. Blackwell suggests that collaborative learning around the technology makes the difference and recommends that schools reconsider how tablets are used, especially in earlier grades. The findings will be presented at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico.

The passage describes a piglet born without back legs that has learned to walk on its front trotters, becoming an internet sensation. The piglet, nicknamed 'Super Pig,' is shown in a video taking unsteady steps but maintaining balance, even when it seems close to tipping over. It lives with its littermates, who all have four legs, and belongs to a farmer named Ms. Duan in Qionglai City, China. The piglet has attracted many visitors and is not the first two-legged animal to gain attention in China, as a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also became famous for walking on its front paws.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was hit by Francesco Dracone's car during the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana. Phillips, a tire changer for Dale Coyne Racing, was injured on lap 25 and taken to the infield care center for treatment. He received stitches for a leg injury and was released. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box, causing the incident, and did not finish the race. Rain before the race caused traction issues for many cars.

The passage describes a horrific incident where a man, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally attacked and killed his wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, a dancer known by her stage name Amanda Bueno. The attack was captured on CCTV, showing Severiano smashing his wife's head into concrete paving 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. He later confessed to the crime, stating he was motivated by jealousy of men looking at her. The couple had been married for only four days. After the murder, Severiano attempted to flee but was apprehended by police, who found multiple firearms and a bulletproof vest in his possession. He now faces life in jail.

Sarah Wilson, a 41-year-old journalist and author of "I Quit Sugar," openly discussed her struggle with mental illness, revealing that anxiety and other factors once led her to consider taking her own life. She attributed her feelings to mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and distant family, which made her feel isolated and unable to see a way out. Wilson believes that anxiety and depression are linked and that anxiety is becoming increasingly prevalent among Australian women. She has since found some peace with her condition and encourages others to seek help if needed.

An Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, who was seven-months pregnant, was charged with second-degree assault for striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar after finding her using heroin in her bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the charge, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." Oregon law allows physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave. Curtin's attorney argued that the ex-girlfriend had been harassing Curtin and trying to re-engage the boyfriend in addiction. Curtin has since moved on and is living with her parents, while the boyfriend has not been involved in their child's life. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of nearly six years.

Gemma, a pit bull from California, was filmed being fed treats mixed with a broccoli spear. She made a disgusted face upon eating the broccoli and spat it out. Gemma lives with two children, and it's hoped they won't mimic her dislike for greens. When not eating, Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

**Concise Summary:**

- HSBC apologized for a link on its official website that directed visitors to a pornographic page.
- The link was intended for the bank's page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which was shut down after the awards were scrapped in 2011.
- The porn site took over the address after the organizers allowed its registration on hsbc.com.hk to retire.
- HSBC removed the hyperlink after realizing the mistake and denied any association with the external site.
- The bank assured the public that its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old boy named Marcus and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom after a fire broke out in their Clinton, Maryland home. Marcus called 911, providing instructions and staying calm throughout the 11-minute call. He also reassured his sister. Firefighters rescued the siblings through a window, and they were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. Three other family members escaped on their own.

**Summary:**

- Blue fluorescent algae have lit up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay, NSW.
- Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured images of the neon glow, describing it as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light.
- The glow is caused by Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in spring and autumn, usually due to natural causes.
- A similar display occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014.
- Iain Suthers, from the University of New South Wales, explained that the glow is a defense mechanism of the carnivorous cell that preys on another type of algae called diatoms.

The passage discusses a new test called EndoPredict that can help breast cancer patients avoid chemotherapy by analyzing genetic markers in the tumor to determine the risk of recurrence. The test can indicate if the risk is as low as 5%, which is comparable to or better than the odds with chemotherapy. Currently, most women receive chemotherapy after tumor removal, but this test can help them make an informed choice. The test is expensive (around £2,500) and mostly available privately, but there's hope it will be available on the NHS. A patient, Becca Cornford, used this test and opted out of chemotherapy due to a low recurrence risk. Experts like Professor Kefah Mokbel and Surgeon Hemant Singhal support the use of this test.

Over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy in the last nine years, with one ship, HMS Ocean, having five such cases. At least one woman was airlifted from HMS Illustrious, nicknamed 'HMS Lusty'. Eighteen other ships also had emergency evacuations due to pregnancy. The Ministry of Defence confirmed a strict 'no touching' rule at sea. This data follows a 2014 incident where Commander Sarah West was flown back to the UK amid claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and in 2014, about 9% of personnel were female. Additionally, nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan and over 100 from Iraq due to pregnancy. Strict military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material, believed to be cesium, was found on the rooftop of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence in Tokyo. The discovery coincided with a court approval to restart two nuclear reactors. The drone, equipped with a camera and smoke flares, raised concerns about potential drone-related terrorism, especially with upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Japanese law currently has no flight restrictions for drones over most of Tokyo, including government buildings. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was not in his office at the time, as he was attending a conference in Indonesia.

The passage describes a man named Lu Xincai from China who takes extraordinary care of his 84-year-old mother suffering from Alzheimer's. Every day, he takes her to work with him on his motorbike, securing her with a sash. He does this because she has gotten lost before and he fears for her safety when she's alone. His father passed away and with his wife working in another city and his son in school, he feels it's his duty to care for his mother. He ensures she feels safe during their commute and checks on her throughout the day at work, where she has her own room. He sees this as a way to return the care she gave him when he was young.

The passage discusses a study that found an increase in heavy drinking and binge drinking among Americans between 2005 and 2012, with a significant rise among women. Key points include:

- Heavy drinking (exceeding one drink per day for women and two for men) rose by 17.2%.
- Binge drinking (four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion) increased more among women than men.
- In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers.
- The study tracked drinking patterns at the county level, with Madison County, Idaho, having the lowest binge drinking rate (6%) and Menominee, Wisconsin, having the highest (36%).
- Factors contributing to the increase include changing social norms, affordability of alcohol, increased advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies.
- The study analyzed data from about 3.7 million Americans aged 21 and older.

UN officials warn that doctors are putting women and their babies at risk by performing caesarean sections too readily.
